title: Bed Bath & Beyond’s Housewarming Has Yet to Draw Crowds
sub_head: Last quarter’s numbers for the retailer look worse than they are, but there still are good reasons to approach with caution
body:
Bed Bath & Beyond has really started to spruce the place up. It is a shame its housewarming party drew so few guests.
The retailer logged a 5% decline in total revenue and a 2% gain in comparable-store sales in the quarter ended Nov. 28. Both figures were lower than what analysts polled by FactSet had expected. Furthermore, the company posted a net loss of $75.4 million. Analysts had expected a profit.
The disappointing numbers are partly a result of Bed Bath & Beyond’s housecleaning efforts, which could make numbers worse before they get better. Without impacts from divestitures and store closures, the company would have posted a positive bottom line.
Below the surface, the company is showing signs of improvement. Gross margins, for example, improved by more than 3 percentage points last quarter compared with the same period a year earlier and held steady from the preceding quarter. That is actually quite a feat considering that sales were weaker compared with both periods and a much higher share of the retailer’s sales today come from e-commerce.
Digital sales surged 77% year over year for the entire company, which includes Buy Buy Baby. Expanding gross margins are a solid sign that the retailer has gotten savvier about promotions and merchandising. The other number to watch is the retailer’s inventory turnover, a measure of how quickly it sells and replaces items. That metric improved last quarter both compared with the prior quarter and a year earlier.
